dt: {bc}the space taken out of a structural member (such as a timber) to admit the insertion of part of another
{bc}something that covers or protects: such as
{bc}a case or enclosure (as for a mechanical part or an instrument)
{bc}a casing (such as an enclosed bearing) in which a shaft revolves
{bc}a support (such as a frame) for mechanical parts

et: Middle English, from {it}house{/it} housing (from Anglo-French {it}huce, houce{/it}, of Germanic origin) + {it}-ing{/it}; akin to Middle High German {it}hulft{/it} covering

dt: {bc}to provide with living quarters or shelter

dt.t: the barn where they {wi}house{/wi} their boat

dt: {bc}to encase, enclose, or shelter as if by putting in a house {dx_def}see {dxt|house:1||}{/dx_def}

dt.t: so timorous a soul {it}housed{/it} in so impressive a body

dt: {bc}to serve as a shelter or container for {bc}{sx|contain||}

shortdef: to provide with living quarters or shelter
to encase, enclose, or shelter as if by putting in a house

dt: {bc}a group of individual dwellings or apartment houses typically of similar design that are usually built and sold or leased by one management

shortdef: a group of individual dwellings or apartment houses typically of similar design that are usually built and sold or leased by one management

dt: {bc}a publicly supported and administered housing development planned usually for low-income families

shortdef: a publicly supported and administered housing development planned usually for low-income families

dt: {bc}the number of new houses that people started to build

shortdef: the number of new houses that people started to build

dt: {bc}the total number of houses and apartments in an area

shortdef: the total number of houses and apartments in an area

dt: {bc}housing for people who have low incomes

shortdef: housing for people who have low incomes
